summary: This document is a series of email chains from 2019 between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel requesting and approving travel for the Epstein investigation (United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618). The emails detail trips to Los Angeles and West Palm Beach/Fort Lauderdale for victim interviews and meetings, indicating an active phase of the investigation.

connections.description: Both are part of the investigation team traveling for the Epstein case, as indicated in travel requests.

events.title: Travel to Los Angeles for Interview
events.description: Investigation team travels to Los Angeles for an interview (or possibly multiple interviews) with a witness. Specific flight and hotel details are provided.

events.title: Interview in Los Angeles
events.description: The investigation team travels to Los Angeles for an interview.

events.title: Interview in West Palm Beach
events.description: The investigation team (specifically S and another unnamed person) travels to West Palm Beach for an interview, requesting a conference room.

events.title: Victim Interview in Los Angeles
events.description: The investigation team (S, M, and/or others) travels to Los Angeles for a victim interview, requesting a conference room.

events.title: Meetings and Interviews in West Palm Beach
events.description: The investigation team plans travel to West Palm Beach for meetings and interviews with victims, requesting a conference room.

events.title: Travel for Meetings and Interviews
events.description: Travel is requested and approved for the Epstein investigation team to conduct meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida.

events.title: Initial Travel Request for Meetings
events.description: S requests permission to travel to West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale for two days of meetings and interviews related to the Epstein case.

keyFacts: The document reveals an active investigation phase in 2019 under case number United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618, relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity.
Multiple trips were taken by the U.S. Attorney's Office team to Los Angeles and Florida (West Palm Beach/Fort Lauderdale) specifically for victim interviews and meetings.
The travel requests frequently mention the need to book a conference room at a hotel to conduct interviews, indicating formal proceedings.
The correspondence shows a pattern of internal approval for investigation-related travel, with emails forwarded and approved by superiors.
Specific, detailed travel itineraries (flights, hotels, dates) are provided, highlighting the operational planning behind the investigation.
